entry.title: Can I Skip a SAP SuccessFactors Stay Current Assessment and Renew With the Next Release?
entry.content:
Dear Team,

My SAP SuccessFactors certification  (8X since 2017)  is valid until August 2026.

 

With the new SAP policy requiring annual renewal via stay current assessments, I want to know:

Can I skip the upcoming stay current assessment (for 2H 2025) and instead just take the next available one (for 1H 2026) before my certification expiry in August 2026?

Will skipping a release affect my certification validity as long as I renew before my expiry date?

As an Independent Consultant/Architect, I need to invest on Learning Hub myself , that is why I've asked .According to this I need to plan and allocate budget for it.

I tried and checked in Perplexity, got below answers  but I want to get 100 % trusted answers from SAP Official sources?

 

Perplexity says :

Yes, it is allowed to skip the 2H 2025 stay current assessment and appear directly for the 1H 2026 assessment, as long as your certification does not expire in the interim. Your SAP SuccessFactors certifications remain valid until their mentioned expiry in August 2026, provided you complete the necessary stay current or renewal assessment before expiry.

Key Points on SAP SF Certification Renewal

  • SAP SF certifications are now valid for 12 months at a time but can be extended yearly by completing the stay current/delta assessment for the next release.

  • The stay current assessment (linked to each release) is mandatory to push your expiry date forward by another year.

  • Skipping a release: You are not obliged to take every delta assessment (each half-yearly release). You only need to pass the latest available stay current assessment before your certification expires.  (Need clarification on this point)

  • If you skip 2H 2025, you can take the 1H 2026 assessment directly before your expiry date in August 2026, and your certification will be renewed.

Practical Guidance

  • Monitor expiry dates on your SAP Learning Hub dashboard and SAP Universal ID.

  • You will receive automated reminders before your certification expiry.

  • If your certification expires before you complete a stay current assessment, you will need to pass the full exam again to re-certify.

  • Unlimited attempts are allowed for most stay current assessments within the valid term.

Summary Table

Scenario                                            Is It Allowed?                                Certification Validity
Skip 2H 2025, take 1H 2026Yes, if before expiry dateExtended on passing 1H 2026 assessment
Miss expiry deadlineNo, must retake full examCertification lapses
 
 
Best regards,
Dr. Niladri Bihari Nayak
Enterprise Architect
Architecting for a Better World!

entry.title: A Beginner‚Äôs Learning Venture with Gen AI to Create a Chat Assistant.
entry.content:
No doubt Gen AI term has grabbed the attention of the whole world. And everyone now wants to try out its potential. Chat GPT, Google Gemini has become everyone‚Äôs personal assistant to get things drafted, to get ideas, to get potential solutions over technical error etc.

It has become a topic of discussion in every company and as a goal for individuals for next review meet üòâ

 

But well, it‚Äôs interesting to know, how do these things work out.

Tried out our own SAP AI Core to get a hands-on by creating a chat assistant.

Purpose: To use ‚Äògenerative-ai-hub-sdk‚Äô to access the ‚Äògpt-35-turbo‚Äô LLM model from SAP's Generative AI Hub in AI Core

 

Few Pre-requisite Steps Required:

  • Provision SAP AI core entitlement in SAP BTP cockpit and create the corresponding instance with sap-internal service plan and generate the service key.
  • The service key details enable to derive the authentication by using the clientid, clientsecret and request auth_url to generate Auth Token. We saved the following values as .env file with below details.

  • Next Create the deployment configuration using the below curl command by providing the executableId, modelName and modelVersion

  • The response of the same would provide configurationid, which needs to be passed to start the deployment, which would in turn provide deploymentId

  • Once the desired LLM is deployed that will help to understand the text-based context, as its built using deep learning techniques, enabling to capture complex patterns in language based on various parameters.

     

     

    Next went ahead with chat completion using the LangChain PromptTemplates. Also tried with memory using langchain.memory  ConversationBufferWindowMemory.

    ChatPromptTemplate helps to structure and format prompts to design multi turn interaction.

    • SystemMessagePromptTemplate sets the initial context or behaviour for the AI.
    • HumanMessagePromptTemplate represents the user's input.
    • AIMessagePromptTemplate is used to generate the AI's response.

     

     

    ‚Äòtemperature‚Äô, ‚Äòmax_tokens‚Äô, and ‚Äòtop_p‚Äô are parameters in a model that determines the behaviour or helps to fine tune the output.

     

    • A higher temperature (e.g., 0.7 to 1.0) makes the output more random and creative, while a lower temperature (e.g., 0.0 to 0.3) makes the output more focused and deterministic.

     

    • max_tokens determine the maximum number of tokens (words or word pieces) that the model can generate in the response.

     

    • top_p controls the cumulative probability for nucleus sampling.

     

    Output:

    May be a small start for people who are still yet to venture out‚Ä¶..

     

     

    Learning References:

    Learning how to use the SAP AI Core service on SAP Business Techn

    Prompt LLMs in the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core & Launchpad | SAP Tutorials

entry.title: Error in SLT data replication DMC_RT_MSG229 - Cannot update logging table in sender system
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am facing an odd issue in a SLT replication landscape which works as following:

Origin System                                                        Central System                            Target System
SAP ECC (version 617, SP 0013) ->  SLT  ( DMIS 2018_1_752, SP 0012) -> HANA DB

Up to last week, the replication of a couple of Z tables was working just fine.

However, it has come to my attention that yesterday the replication started to fail with the following error:

Cannot update logging table in sender system (conversion object Z<z_table_name>)

Message no. DMC_RT_MSG229

 

I have checked the logs, and this happens forall the entries that the replication job runs through (DMC_MT_STARTER_BATCH).

 

I noticed that the logging table exists in SE14 in the source system, and looks fine but not in the ABAP DDIC (i.e., not in SE11 transaction / TADIR table).

I can see that in SLT, the logging tables are setup (LTRC -> Expert Function -> Display Table Information)

I found out that note 3438605 seems to solve it (it is applicable in the system version) but I didn't see the replication stopping and starting fast enough to trigger the problem, so I'm not sure whether this is the case, and I wanted to check if there could be another cause for this issue.

Any guidance is greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

Erick Grilo.

entry.title: Re: My BAS stuck in starting state
entry.content:
Hi Ravi,

I encountered a similar issue where SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) was stuck in a continuous "Starting" state. I raised a support case with SAP, and they requested both a network trace and the devspace ID. After reviewing the information, they reset the status from their end, which resolved the issue.

If you're experiencing the same problem, I recommend raising a case with SAP and providing:

  • Your devspace ID
  • A network trace

You can refer to the following SAP Knowledge Base Article for instructions on capturing the network trace:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2764266

Thanks,
Santhosh.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025: What's in it for the Utilities Industry?
entry.content:
The newest version of SAP S/4HANA has just been released to customers. Here is an overview about its main innovations that are dedicated to the utilities industry:

  • Market process management and prepayment for utilities moved into SAP S/4HANA Utilities: 
    Two former add-ons are now technically part of SAP S/4HANA - which means you do not need to install an add-on any more on top of S/4HANA to take advantage of their rich functionality:
    • Market process management for Utilities , enables you to efficiently model, execute, and monitor your market processes,including message handling for communication with market partners, in liberalized energy markets
    • Prepayment for utilities, offers your customers the option to prepay their energy consumption,

  • Conversational search on application help (SAP S/4HANA Utilities) through the Joule copilot allows you to express questions to SAP S/4HANA Utilities in natural language and have them instantly answered based on the available SAP Help Portal documentation.

  • Using SAP Datasphere in the utilities industry ‚Äì utilities sales contracts
    You can now extract utilities sales contract data from S/4HANA Utilities to SAP Datasphere for comprehensive analytics and reporting purposes, also leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud. This capability enables utilities companies to leverage their sales contract data for advanced business intelligence and decision-making.
    For a complete overview of available CDS views that enable extraction of utilities business objects to SAP Datasphere, see CDS Views for Utilities Business Objects and Application Areas.

  • Innovation Sales integration interface: discounting, process resilience, and scheduling offers automatic restart capabilities to recover temporary disruptions in the sales process for energy products.

  • Utilities product integration layer (UPIL) support for price guarantees is now available based on an enhanced appointment management for utilities sales contracts, enabling you to define and maintain period control data more effectively.

  • Customization for date fields in utilities contracts allows you to efficiently manage contract durations, renewal dates, and other scheduling data. 


  • Following the Customer Fields and Logic concept of SAP NetWeaver, it is now easier to add your own additional attributes to the point-of-delivery master data and to clarification cases, see Enabling custom fields and logic for point-of-delivery and BPEM case data. Key-user extensibility is one element of SAP's Clean Core strategy, see SAP note 3406389 for a comprehensive overview on Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Utilities.

  • Business events for technical objects for utilities  enables integration of SAP S/4HANA Utilities with external applications. SAP S/4HANA 2025 provide such events for the entities connection object, device location, premise, installation and point of delivery, Note that business events are already available for utilities sales contracts.

  • Budget billing plans in the Business Partner Financial Overview app
    The SAP Fiori app Business Partner Financial Overview now includes a new facet showing further utilities-industry specific data

If you want to learn more about the previous release (SAP S/4HANA 2023) please see the following SAP Community blog posts 

 SAP S/4HANA release
(and feature pack)		Available
since

entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customer‚Äôs Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective it‚Äôs very sensitive step as it‚Äôs reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. It‚Äôs helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

Purchasing Group

Actual procurement team or buyer

Commodity teams, regional buyers

A Visual Approach to Mapping

I'm a visual learner, so diagrams really help me solidify these concepts. I've created a couple of diagrams to illustrate how a typical departmental structure might map to SAP organizational units, and how those units relate to each other.
Here's a conceptual mapping from real-world departments to SAP units:

And here's a more detailed example of what a complete SAP organizational hierarchy might looks like, incorporating multiple company codes, plants, and purchasing organizations:

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.

I hope my thoughts and findings has been helpful for you, and I'm always learning new things about SAP organizational structures, so I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences.

  • What challenges have you faced when mapping customer's organization in SAP?
  • What advice would you give to SAP community members or for a someone has just starting out?
  • Have you encountered any particularly creative or unusual organizational structure designs?

SAP ERP SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: Master Data In SAP Plant Maintenance
entry.content:
In SAP we have two different types of data namely:- 

  • Master Data
  • Transactional Data 

For any person who is working in the SAP should know about what is transactional data and what are master data. Because each of the module have different types of master data and different transactional data in SAP.

Master Data:-

The data which is created and cannot be changed frequently it means once the data is being created in the system then this data will be accessed frequently but the changes to this data will not being done.

Example:- Materials, Equipments, Functional Location, Permits, source list, Purchase info Record, Customer Info Record etc.. .

Transactional Data:-

The data which is created based on master data it means that this data will be created upon by using the master data components.

Example:- Notifications, Maintenance Orders, Work Order confirmations, Sales orders, Purchase Orders etc.... 

Master data Components in SAP Plant Maintenance:- 

1. Functional Location:- we use Functional Location in SAP PM to identify where the technical object equipment is being installed. It is mainly used to prioritize the maintenance technician to find the equipment or machine that is being installed in a Plant.

Main components of functional location :-  Structure Indicator , Edit mask, Hierarchy Levels

2. Equipment:- Equipment is one of the type of technical object in which we will create machines that are being used in production to manufacture the finished goods.

3.Serial Numbers:- Serial numbers is considered as master data as it means same specifications machines will be installed in the plant right so serial numbers is master data. And this is the point where the SAP PM integrates SAP MM(Material Management).

4. Work Center:- A group of people who are responsible for work is known as work center. Mostly in the naming convention will be ELECXXXX or MECHXXX. It means that the department with number convention is mostly being used in sap.

5.Bill Of Materials:- BOM is being used in various departments like production , sales etc... but when it comes to plant maintenance it is used as the materials that are needed to maintain the equipment or material that are being used in equipment reference purpose. For more information about Bill Of materials navigate to the link below:-

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/bill-of-materials-bom/ba-p/14145696 

6.Maintenance Plan:- A plan is created which will generate the orders, notifications, Service Procurement etc.. based on scheduling parameters.

7. Catalogs & Code Groups:- It is a integration part in SAP PM with SAP QM. Catalogs Profile is given by the Quality Management team in which we have code groups. In Code groups they will maintain the object parts that are present in the equipment , cause and damage of equipment parts etc.... 

8.Measuring Points & Counter:- Measuring points and counter plays a crucial role in Equipments as they were used for maintaining the recording or readings of equipment after using them. For example : Micrometer, thermometer etc....

9.Task List:- The tasks that are being executed every time or else we can tell as like the tasks that needs to be performed are listed in a structured format.
There are 3 types of task list in plant maintenance namely

  • Equipment task list: - This is mainly used for equipments only. The tasks that are required for needed to be done for the equipment.
  • Functional Location Task List: - This is mainly used for specific functional locations in which the tasks are to be performed.
  • General Task List: - This will be created for general purpose, reusable resources, across multiple equipments as well as functional locations.

10.Material Master:- Material master is also considered as master data in sap pm because the materials that are required for maintaining the equipment or the materials.

11. Employee Master Data:- Employee master data in which the assignment of employee for technical object or else the assignment of employee for work center etc.. are being assigned and these employee id and employee creation will be done by human capital management system(HCM). This is an integration point where the module HCM integrate with PM.

Transactional Data:-

1. Notification:- Notification is created whenever any maintenance is required for equipment or malfunction is being held at an equipment. Then to notify the persons in the plant they will create the notification by using of master data.

2. Work Order/Maintenance Order: - The materials which are required for maintenance activities will be assigned here in the maintenance order. For cost collection purpose it means the activities or task that are being done by a maintenance technician will be collected here. 

3. Confirmation: - The activities that are being carried out by the maintenance technician will be confirmed by the production supervisor or else the production department who is working at the machines or equipments.

4. Settlement Of Maintenance Order/ Production Order: - Generally this will be carried out by the FICO team but the settlement of an order can be done after performing the TECO or else the order cannot be settled. Here the settlement will be done against order otherwise the cost that are being collected in the maintenance order will not be posted to the cost elements. These cost elements will not post the costs to the g/l accounts which are present in the Finance accounts.

5. Measurement Documents: - These are the documents that keeps on changing whenever there is a use of equipments like PRT tools, or else any meters that are being used for checking the equipments. The values will be entered while performing the confirmation in IW41.

DATA UPLOAD SEQUENCE IN SAP:- 
So for suppose you are working on the implementation project and wanted to upload the master data so we will just follow the below sequence, It is best sequence as per  my knowledge.

Summary:- 

In every SAP module, both master data and transactional data play a crucial role in executing business processes. Earlier, I explained these two types of data in detail for SAP Plant Maintenance.

For example, in the SAP MM (Materials Management) module, the master data includes elements such as Material Master, Source List, Purchase Info Record, Service Master, and Vendor Master. The transactional data in MM involves activities like Purchase Order (PO), MIGO (Goods Receipt), and MIRO (Invoice Verification).

Similarly, in the SAP SD (Sales and Distribution) module, the master data consists of Pricing Conditions, Sales Organization, Division, Sales Area, and Shipping Point.

In short, every SAP module has its own specific master and transactional data, which together ensure smooth and integrated business operations across the system.

entry.title: Enhancements to Event-Based Variance Calculation with OP2025
entry.content:
When SAP delivered event-based variance calculation in combination with Universal Parallel Accounting with OP2022 three categories of variances were missing: output price variances, mixed price variances and scrap variances, as documented in the SAP Note giving the scope of Universal Parallel Accounting Universal Parallel Accounting: Scope Information  and in my original blog  The Differences between Traditional and Event-based WIP and Variance Calculation.

With OP2023, FPS2 SAP reintroduced output price variances and with OP2025, FPS0 SAP reintroduces mixed price variances and scrap variances. With these developments, the event-based approach reaches functional parity with the classic approach to variance calculation, though the posting logic is fundamentally different.

Variance Categories in the Universal Journal

The settings for event-based variance calculation are delivered with scope item 3F0 and can only be used in private cloud or on-premise systems in combination with the business function Universal Parallel Accounting. Figure 1 shows the new categories Mixed Price Variance, Scrap Variance and Output Price Variance under Active Variance Categories where the Variance Split is active. You can check these settings by following Controlling > Product Cost Controlling > Product Cost by Order > Period-End Closing > Event-Based WIP and Variance Posting in the IMG. We‚Äôll begin by explaining these variance categories and look at the other enhancements to the Event-Based Processing Key later.

Figure 1: Active Variance Categories for Event-Based Processing Key

All variance categories are stored in the universal journal with reference to the G/L account for the gains/losses from price differences and a Subledger-Specific Line Item Type (see Figure 2), where 9133 is used for the Scrap Variance, 9137 for the Mixed Price Variance and 9138 for the Output Price Variance, as shown in Figure 2. These categories are delivered by SAP and cannot be changed.

 

Figure 2: Variance Categories as Subledger-Specific Line Item Types

If you use the legacy document display (transaction FB03) to view the variances on a production order, as shown in Figure 3, then you will see different lines for the price difference posting in total and the split to the variance categories under the G/L account Gain on Production Variances (52570000 in our example). To view the variance categories in reporting, you should use the Order Cost Details app (F4254), the Production Cost Overview - Event-Based (F6248) app, the Product Profitability with Production Variances app (W0182), the Display Line Items ‚Äì Production Accounting app (F7288) or the Display Line Items ‚Äì Margin Analysis app (F4818).

Figure 3: Journal Entry showing Total Variances and Variance Categories

With the event-based approach, there is no need to perform a separate settlement step to move the production variances from Production Accounting to Margin Analysis as the journal entries for variance calculation are automatically linked with the product-related market segments at the time of posting, as shown in Figure 4 where we see that the Account Assignments for both the Order and the Profitability Segment have been filled automatically for the selected line item.

Figure 4: Line Item for Production Variances Showing Assignment to Production Order and to Profitability Segment

Now let‚Äôs focus on the new variance categories in more detail.

Output Price Variances

Output price variances occur if the standard price changes between the time that the finished goods are delivered into stock and the time when the variances are calculated and represents the difference between the actual credit and target credit of an order. If you always deliver the full order lot size to stock, then you will immediately trigger a variance calculation with the event-based approach. However, they can occur if there are multiple deliveries of the finished goods into stock over a longer time frame or you use manual settlement (see Trigger for Variance Settlement later).

Mixed Price Variances

Mixed price variances occur when the standard costs for the material produced are based on the cost estimates for multiple procurement alternatives whose usage is weighted and then mixed to provide a standard cost that reflects the various options. Each option to make or buy the material is represented as a procurement alternative and mixed price variances occur for production orders, when the credit posting for the delivery to stock does not match the value in the mixed cost estimate.

Looking at mixed costing in terms of variance calculation, the input variances are calculated with respect to the procurement alternative used as a basis for production. In this way, you‚Äôll see any input price variances, input quantity variances and resource-usage variances with respect to the material components and operations used in the production version being manufactured, together with any lot-size variances on the output side. The other output variances, in other words, those variances referring to the value used to deliver the finished goods into stock, are affected by the mixed cost estimate used to set the standard price. Figure 5 illustrates the high-level approach.

Figure 5: Innovation Highlight for Mixed Price Variances

The easiest way to visualize the impact of a mixed cost estimate is to imagine a situation where the values recorded in production are exactly the same as those used for the preliminary cost estimate (in other words, there are no input variances and the order lot size is delivered to stock), but the delivery of the goods into stock is valuated using the mixed price rather than the total planned costs for the procurement alternative. That difference is the mixed price variance, and you‚Äôll find the new variance category in all Fiori apps that show production variances. Figure 6 shows the variances on production order 1000962 in the Order ‚Äì Event-Based app.

Figure 6: Mixed-Price Variance Column in Order ‚Äì Event-Based App

If you are familiar with mixed costing from previous editions, then there is no change to the way you calculate standard costs based on multiple procurement alternatives with the event-based approach. The transactions to create procurement alternatives (CK91N) and define the mixing ratios (CK94 and CK95) have simply been returned to the menu and you‚Äôll find the fields MKALK (Mixed Costing) and BALTKZ (Cost Estimate for a Procurement Alternative) in the KEKO and CKIS tables where the results of the standard cost estimate are stored. There are also no changes to the calculation of the planned costs on the production order under plan category PLANORD01 (Order Plan/Preliminary Cost), since these are specific to the production version for the order.

However, with the reintroduction of mixed costing, there is a change to the update of plan category PLANORD02 (Material Cost Estimate (Inventory View)), since this now has two levels, where the top level reflects the mixed costing (identified by the field MKALK)  where several different cost estimates have been weighted to calculate the standard costs for the material and the lower level refers to the individual cost estimates that were included in the mix, each of which are identified by the field BALTKZ (Cost Estimate for a Procurement Alternative). These fields together with additional fields to identify the quantity structure have been added to the ACDOCP table.

The impact of mixed costing is reflected in both the calculation of target costs and the variance split and in the valuation of work in process where this is based on the target costs. Target costs are calculated for both the mixed level and each procurement alternative.

Scrap Variances

Scrap variances occur when scrap is recorded during production. In many cases the standard costs for the material produced already include a value for the planned scrap based on the entries in the master data and the scrap variance calculates the difference between the planned scrap and the actual scrap recorded. The high-level process is illustrated in Figure 7.

Figure 7: Innovation Highlight for Scrap Variances

If you are familiar with the use of planned scrap from previous editions, then there is no change to the way you calculate standard costs to include the scrap factors defined for the finished product at assembly level or at operation level, or indeed for component scrap in the bill of material. The additional costs for the planned scrap continue to be shown in the itemization for the standard costs, if you select the scrap layout (1SAP08 ‚Äì Planned Scrap). The calculation of planned scrap for the production or process order also takes place as before. Figure 8 shows the planned scrap by operation for a process order.

Figure 8: Itemization showing Planned Scrap Values for Raw Materials and Activities

As with the mixed price variances, the change for the planned costs with the update to the ACDOCP table which has been extended to include new fields for the assembly and component scrap quantities and the associated scrap factors. This information can then be used to determine the scrap variance when actual scrap is confirmed either at operation level or at order level.

As we can see in Figure 8, planned scrap is captured at operation level and so it is important to record scrap at the same granularity. With the event-based approach, the scrap valuation is based on the structure of the routing in the preliminary cost estimate so that the recorded values can be compared line-by-line with those used in planning.

Again, you won‚Äôt be able to see the Subledger-Specific Line Item Types for the scrap variances in the classic user interfaces, but the Fiori apps have been extended to show the Scrap Variances as a new variance category. Figure 9 shows the scrap variance for the raw material usage associated with scrapped goods.

Figure 9: Scrap Variance for Raw Material Consumption

Cost Objects supported in the Event-based Approach

My original article described how to use the event-based approach to variance calculation for production orders and process orders, but from OP2023 it is possible to use this approach for product cost collectors with repetitive manufacturing (in this case the WIP Calculation Method switches to WIP at Target Costs) and CO production orders for outsourced manufacturing. With OP2025 it is also possible to use the event-based approach for CO production orders created manually using transaction KKF1.

Trigger for Variance Settlement

While the event-based approach clearly brings benefits in terms of real-time cost transparency, there can also be challenges in a high-volume environment with many WIP documents being created and cancelled in quick succession. For this reason, SAP has introduced the option to calculate the WIP and variances manually by setting the Order Settlement Trigger Type to Settled Manually instead of Based on Business Event (see Figure 1). It is planned to introduce this option with OP2025, FPS1. While this might seem like a return to the classic approach, the posting logic is different with the new WIP and variance documents resulting in journal entries that update the WIP and variance categories as Subledger-Specific Line Item Types.

Further Information

If you are new to the topic of variance calculation, then you might find it helpful to read one of my books on the topic: 

Controlling with SAP S/4HANA Business User Guide 

Product Cost Controlling with SAP S/4HANA 

Production Variance Analysis in SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: IC Stock Transfer Returns Process w/ outbound and inbound delivery (Private Cloud / On Prem)
entry.content:
Long time before I was born üòâ, the intercompany return process did not include a return delivery or an inbound delivery. You needed to use MIGO in the returning plant to post into transit and in the receiving plant the stock transport delivery was posted with a reversed movement. Intercompany return stock transfer process | SAP Help Portal

Meanwhile, we need a return delivery for the EWM or TM activities. As well as an inbound delivery for the receiving plant which contains all the handling unit / batch information from the returning plant. 

SAP realized this process already with the "Store Return" process. And they finetuned it with the Advanced Returns Management.  Maybe you don't need all the replacement functions or inspection functions because you basically just want to return something to another cross-company plant. 

In SPRO, you can read all the required setup steps and which standard configuration (PO, delivery, movement types,...) is available in client 000

SAP Customizing Implementation Guide->Materials Management->Purchasing->Purchase Order->Returns Order->Store Return / Return Plant to Plant

 

  1. A return PO is created (with return flag in the item).
  2. In the shipping data of the return PO you will notice that the sales area is now determined from the returning plant.
  3. You create a return delivery (VL10b) in the returning plant, pick and post goods issue.
  4. The output type SPED in the return delivery triggers the automatic creation of the inbound delivery in the receiving plant.
  5. In inbound warehouse tasks are executed and you post goods receipt.
  6. The receiving plant creates the SD credit note against the returning plant.
  7. The returning plant creates the vendor credit note against the SD credit note (or receives it via IDoc)

Bascially, it covers all features of advanced stock transfer BUT

  1. No financial transit stock postings (after the stock is posted goods issue in the returning plant, the stock belongs to the receiving plant immediately)
  2. There is no transfer of control feature.
  3. No automatic sales return order in the receiving plant.

In SAP KBA 2967795 - Advanced Returns Management: Product Overview Documents - SAP for Me I found also some good material which explains the scenario:

‚ÑπÔ∏èAll of this can be used w/o ARM features

 

To avoid the ARM, deactivate the feature in the PO type. You only need the "Enhanced Store Returns", but NOT the "Advanced Returns".

This is as documented by SAP. With this setup, you don't use any ARM features, but you activate the store return features which is not part of ARM. 

 

 

Now a quick walk through with best practice demo data. 

Germany 1010 transferred something to US 1710 with advanced STO. Both countries celebrate the effortless new process in S/4HANA.

One piece of their main product TG11 must be returned from US to Germany.

A return PO of type NB2C will be created in US (in the PO type customizing, the ARM feature is not active as shown above).

The STO is created like the former one. Please note that you must not use the PO type which you used for the Advanced IC STO. (Read the restrictions and general information 3226677 - SAP S/4HANA 2022: Restrictions and General Information for Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer - SAP for Me)

In the shipping tab, the sales area of the returning plant is automatically set. Usually in a STO you see the sales area of the supplying plant. In addition, a confirmation control key must be set (Inbound Delivery) what is also new to return items.

With VL10b the return delivery is created in US. In my case, no EWM is used, only IM. 

To automatically create an inbound delivery in Germany after the goods issue posting, the delivery output type SPED is added (or automatically found with condition record)

 

The inbound delivery was created in Germany

In Germany, the putaway activities are done (here again only IM) and confirmed with a goods receipt posting

Finally, the Germans create an internal credit memo for the received product

The credit note could trigger the INVOIC idoc to US, so that the vendor invoice (credit note) is also automatically posted.

This is not setup here, so I post it manually in MIRO in US company code

The whole document flow in ME23N

I hope that the advanced IC stock transfer will also cover the return scenario in the near future but for now, this standard process with store returns will help us to bridge until we get new innovations by SAP.

If you have any remarks or hints regarding TM integration, please feel free to share your experiences.

Thanks.

entry.title: SAP Supply Chain Management Certification: Increase Your Expertise and Credibility
entry.content:
Running sustainable, resilient supply chains amid disruptions has become a driving force in many organizations. While supply chains have historically prioritized efficiency and cost reduction, digital technologies are delivering incredible gains to achieve even greater outcomes, while connecting processes and enabling faster insights.

In these times of rapid innovation, it‚Äôs becoming increasingly more critical to stay informed of the latest positioning guidance for SAP Supply Chain solutions. SAP has addressed this need by offering a non-technical certification option: Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management Solutions. The non-technical certifications options are designed to be completed in a matter of few hours, thus making it a great option for individuals who are new to certification, looking to replace an expired certification, or simply interested in cultivating expertise in selling SAP Supply Chain solutions. 

Becoming certified in SAP Supply Chain Management solutions will prepare you to gain the confidence and trust in your biggest stakeholder, the Chief Operating Officer (‚ÄúCOO‚Äù). 

The self-paced learning content will cover these key areas:

  • The end-to-end solution portfolio and how it addresses key priorities for the COO
  • How to position Supply Chain Management solutions in the context of SAP Business Suite
  • How AI is being used today in modern business settings as well as how it fits into the SAP‚Äôs Business AI strategy.
  • Selling SAP Supply Chain Management solutions to the COO through qualification, discovery, and packaging. 

Upon completing the digital learning, your certification attainment is achieved by:

  • Submission of one of the following hands-on exercises:
    • Articulating the value of SAP Supply Chain solutions through an executive pitch
    • Demonstrating the value of SAP Supply Chain solution by performing a demo.
  • Successful completion of a one-hour exam that will include thirty questions derived from the self-paced learning content.

Don‚Äôt Delay‚Äîtake advantage of this opportunity to establish your credibility in SAP Supply Chain Management and showcase your accomplishment. With around 5 hours of self-paced learning, this certification option is achievable for any busy professional and will provide tangible value in your field of expertise. Visit the SAP Learning Site to review the available certifications and select Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management so you can start expertly positioning SAP‚Äôs Supply Chain Management solutions to solve your customer‚Äôs key challenges and deliver real-world results.

Lauren Edwards

SAP Industries & Experience, Partner Solution Enablement, SAP Supply Chain Management

entry.title: Use Case for the Incident Number during Nonconformance logging in SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Introduction

The Incident Number attribute in SAP DM is a property of the nonconformance (NC) record that has been created.  It has its origins dating back to the SAP ME application and has been implemented in SAP DM.

The original business use case was intended to have an attribute that would be created at the start of an NC Incident to serve as a reference point that could be used by subsequent NC records and actions.   Both additional primary NC records and secondary/tertiary NC records can be linked to this Incident Number and serve as a way to group or "chain" the entire NC record associated with the SFC's NC initial Incident.

 

Process Overview

The usage of the Incident Number follows these steps:

  1. Specification of the format of the Incident Number generation (for the Automatic case),
  2. Enabling the use of Incident Numbers in the NC Data Entry POD Plug-In.
  3. Logging the primary NC record and specifying the Incident Number, either Manually or Automatically.
  4. Optional: Logging one or more secondary NC records, typically using the NC Data Tree POD plug-in, and adding the Incident Number created in the logging of the primary NC to serve as a linkage and perform a "chain" or grouping of the NC records. 
  5. Utilizing the recorded NC Incident chain information for Reporting and Analytics. 

 

Configuration

Next Number: Specifying the format of the Incident Number

The format of the Incident Number can be defined in the Manage Next Number application on the Incident Number tab.  The default prefix is 'IN' but this can be changed according to specific requirements for the business.  This example in the screenshot shows a suffix using Replaceable Time Parameters.

 

 

Nonconformance Data Entry POD Plug-In: Incident Number Options

These are the options for the Incident Number generation from the NC Data Entry POD plug-in in the POD Designer application:

  • None: The system omits the Incident Number field.
  • Manual: Operators must enter the Incident Number in the POD.
  • Automatic: The system automatically generates an Incident Number based on the numbering pattern you define in the Incident Number section of the Manage Next Numbers application.

The Incident Number does not have to be explicitly defined in the NC Data Type that is assigned to an NC Code.  The POD Plug-In configuration enables this field.

 

Usage

After the configuration has been completed, perform the nonconformance logging process for an SFC in the POD.

The Incident Number will be the first data field in the NC Data Entry plug-in below the NC Code/Attachments field.  It will be above the other fields from the NC Data Type assigned to that NC Code. 

There is a value help (browse) the operator can select to choose an existing Incident Number.  This is used when associating a new NC record to an existing NC incident chain.  Likewise, if this is the start of a new NC chain, the Incident Number can be manually specified or the system-generated Incident Number (shown in the screenshot) can be used.

New NC records can then be added using the NC Data Tree in this scenario.  This in effect continues building the Incident chain.  Typically, secondary NC codes are added for the chain.   A typical chain consists of the Primary NC record, usually indicating a test failure or inspection detected defect along with one or more Secondary NC records.  The Secondary NC chain can, in theory, go 'n' levels deep but typically the subsequent Secondary NC records are associated with repairs, root causes or corrective actions.

The screenshot below is in a standalone NC logging POD with the NC Data Tree assigned.  This is where the Secondary NC records are added and linked using the Incident Number associated with a Primary NC record. 

 

 

Reporting

Each NC record created that has an assigned Incident Number is stored in the nonconformance database and is also sent to the DM Insights Manufacturing Data Object for nonconformances.   Specific Insight's dashboards can be created in Manage Dashboards to meet the specific requirements for reporting and analytics using the Incident Number.

The logged NC records can also be retrieved using the public API   that contains the Incident Number for each record that can be collated and used for use cases such as custom reports or custom applications.

entry.title: Reinventing B2B Customer Experiences with the SAP B2B Self-Service Portal
entry.content:
Why B2B Needs a Makeover

Today‚Äôs B2B customers expect the same seamless, personalised, and transparent experiences they enjoy as consumers. Relying only on sales representatives and support desks is no longer enough. Customers want 24/7 access, instant transparency, and simplified digital processes.

That‚Äôs where the SAP B2B Self-Service Portal comes in. More than just a convenience layer, it digitalizes routine customer interactions‚Äîsuch as tracking orders, downloading invoices, and making online payments‚Äîwhile freeing sales and support teams to focus on strategic, value-driven conversations with customers.

The Challenges B2B Organisations Face

Across industries, B2B companies and its Customers often struggle with the below challenges:

These issues directly affect both customer satisfaction, business operation efficiencies and cash flow.

SAP B2B Self-Service Portal: A Digital Entry Point

SAP‚Äôs foundational B2B Self-Service Portal , seamlessly integrated with SAP S/4HANA, provides a digital entry point for customer engagement‚Äîwithout the complexity of a full transactional commerce platform.

What it Delivers

  • Transparency: Customers can track orders, invoices, and payment status in real-time.
  • Convenience: Self-service for downloads, requests, and account management.
  • Efficiency: Routine tasks shift from support desks to the portal, reducing sales friction.
  • Consistency: Data is synced directly with SAP S/4HANA for reliable, real-time accuracy.

This makes the portal an ideal launchpad for digital engagement, giving organisations a fast, lightweight way to improve customer experience and operational efficiency.

Key Capabilities of the Foundational B2B Self Service Portal

  • Account Management ‚Äì login, password, and organisation management
  • Orders ‚Äì order lists, details, and sync from S/4HANA
  • Financials ‚Äì invoices, credit notes, credit limits, invoice downloads
  • Content Management ‚Äì home page, promo banners, contact forms
  • Master Data Integration ‚Äì B2B units and customers
  • Payments (Optional) ‚Äì payment processing, reconciliation, and tracking

From Self-Service to Full B2B Commerce

The journey doesn‚Äôt stop with a self-service portal‚Äîit‚Äôs only the beginning. The portal is designed to evolve with organisation's business needs as below.

Step1: Start with a non-transactional SAP B2B Foundational Self-Service Portal to track Orders, View/download Invoices and make Payments online 

Step2: Upgrade to a full scale transactional SAP Commerce Cloud to enable advanced capabilities such as online ordering, personalised catalogs, real-time pricing with inventory management and many more.

Step3: Extend into a connected commerce ecosystem by integrating with other SAP CX Solutions creating a complete digital experience for both customers and business teams.

Getting Started with SAP Activation Services

To accelerate adoption, SAP provides a baseline Activation Service that quickly sets up the portal. With the support of an SAP Partner, this baseline can be extended into a full Go-Live service, ensuring smooth rollout and faster time-to-market.

For organisations looking to improve cash flow, the SAP Digital Payments Add-On can be integrated. This enables online invoice payments with automatic reconciliation in SAP S/4HANA Finance, reducing manual effort, speeding up collections, and giving finance teams real-time visibility into outstanding balances.

Prerequisites and Services

  • SAP B2B Self-Service Portal Add-On - Link
  • SAP Digital Payments Add-On ‚Äì Link
  • SAP BTP Integration Suite 
  • Services:  Baseline Activation + Go-Live Services with SAP Partners

Conclusion: From ‚ÄúNice-to-Have‚Äù to ‚ÄúMust-Have‚Äù

In today‚Äôs digital-first world, a B2B Self-Service Portal is no longer optional. It is essential for organizations that want to remain competitive by delivering transparency, speed, and convenience to customers‚Äîwhile freeing sales and support teams to focus on relationship-building and growth.

And this is just the beginning. With SAP Commerce Cloud, businesses can expand from self-service to full-fledged B2B e-commerce, unlocking advanced capabilities that transform the portal into a comprehensive, connected commerce platform‚Äî redefining what B2B customer experience can be.

entry.title: Re: Issue with sales order creation
entry.content:
The difference between VA01 & BAPI is

In VA01, the ATP check and schedule line determination are fully executed before SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE is triggered. So by the time your user exit runs, XVBEP[] is fully populated.

In BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2, the ATP check and schedule line determination may not be completed yet when SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE is triggered. This means XVBEP[] might only contain the initial schedule line (e.g., with 0 confirmed quantity), and the second line is added later in the process. The BAPI doesn‚Äôt commit changes automatically. If the external system calls BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT after the BAPI, the second schedule line might be added after your user exit has already run.

You mentioned XVBEP[] in one place and XVBRP[] in another. Just to clarify:

  • Delivery schedule proposals are not stored in XVBRP[]

Make sure you're consistently checking XVBEP[] in all the cases.

I would recommend to follow the below steps

Use VBEP Instead of XVBEP in BAPI Context. If XVBEP[] is not fully populated, consider reading directly from VBEP using the item number (VBAP-POSNR) and sales document number (VBAK-VBELN) ‚Äî but only if the document has already been created.

If your logic depends on finalized schedule lines, consider moving it to a later user exit like SAVE_DOCUMENT (after the document is saved) or USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT in MV45AFZZ

Force ATP check in BAPI input and that the schedule lines are passed correctly to trigger ATP.

Hi @kezelda , 

I'm afraid I can't help you 100%, and I don't know why that problem occurs to you. However perhaps you could try and create more "specific" processing rules? That means, processing rules with more detailed actions?
You can, for example, select the AP/AR Posting action type and select specific customer or supplier accounts to be posted to in the processing  rule. Or you could try the Clear in Sequence action type and select a sequence of processing instructions that can process your items one after another.

These alternative actions might be more useful for your case than the 001 interpretation algorithm. For more information, see: 

  • How to Create Processing Rules 
  • Overview on All Predelivered Processing Instructions 
  • Allocation Algorithms

Best regards,
Anita

entry.title: Re: Understanding the Behavior of the Payment Block in th...
entry.content:
Hello @SatoMasayoshi 

The Payment Block in Manage Supplier Master (company code view) is a default setting that adds a payment-block key to new supplier items, excluding them from Manage Automatic Payments unless unblocked at the item level. It doesn‚Äôt change old items retroactively or stop postings. SAP Help Portal-Block Master Data - Customer & Supplier

If your goal is to prevent postings entirely, use a central posting block on the business partner

Block reasons or keys used on items are stored in ‚ÄúDefine Reasons for Payment Blocks‚Äù (configuration). SAP Help Portal-Changing Payment Block and Payment Method

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Restrict users from editing a parked invoice
entry.content:
Since:

  • You‚Äôre not using workflow,
  • You want to restrict editing parked invoices,
  • And the catalog SAP_FIN_BC_AP_INV_MGMT_PC is unavailable,

Here‚Äôs what you can do:

Look for catalogs like:

These catalogs may vary by tenant and release version. Use the ‚ÄúMaintain Business Roles‚Äù app to search for catalogs containing ‚ÄúAP_INV‚Äù or ‚ÄúINVOICE‚Äù.

In the Maintain Business Roles app, select the role assigned to restricted users. Go to Maintain Restrictions.

For relevant catalogs:

  • Set Write Access ‚Üí No Access or Restricted
  • Set Read Access ‚Üí Unrestricted

Use available Restriction Types like:

  • Document Type
  • Company Code
  • Posting Status (if available)

Since Invoice Status is not available, Posting Status may help distinguish parked vs. posted invoices.

If standard role restrictions are insufficient, consider custom Business logic via In-App extensibility, BAdI Implementation (if allowed in public cloud), Field Control or UI Adaptation to disable edit buttons based on status. These options depend on your edition and extensibility scope.

entry.title: Re: How to Create Material Document Movements with Refere...
entry.content:
SAP provides two key APIs for Material Document Posting

  • API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV (OData) Material Documents - Read, Create
  • MATERIALDOCUMENTCREATEREQUEST1 (SOAP) Material Document - Create 

You can build a custom RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) application or schedule background jobs that consume these APIs:

RAP App: Use API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV in your service binding to post GRs from a Fiori app or external trigger.

Background Job: Use the SOAP API for batch processing of GRs, especially for high-volume or scheduled operations.

Make sure to assign the correct communication scenario (SAP_COM_0108), Configure communication arrangements in the Communication Management app. Use Business Catalogs like SAP_MM_BC_INV_DOC_PROC_PC for role-based access

entry.title: Re: Automatic quantity confirmation via TAG
entry.content:
Hello Jair,

If the relevant quantity is provided via Tag form the automation equipment and is processed in a PPD, the intended use would be to call the SFC Complete API/Service directly in that PPD (or a second sub-PPD if required). the POD can be subscribed to SFC Events and will automatically update the displayed quantities (in work and completed).

But maybe this is not the process you intend to implement? Maybe you want only want to provide the quantity to the operator and they should then manually trigger the next steps on the POD? than maybe you could use the machine input to start this poartial quantity via the SFC Start API/Service.

Let me know if this helps or if I went in the wrong direction.

Best regards, Michael

entry.title: Re: A production order compnonent material 101 mvmt displ...
entry.content:
In MB51, double-click the material document. Check the reference document. Is it linked to a production order, purchase order, or other document? Look at the document header ‚Üí field Reference Document (AUFNR) or Order Number. If the reference is not a production order, the movement may have been posted manually or via another process (e.g., MIGO, MB1A).

Go to CO03 ‚Üí enter the production order. Navigate to Component Overview. Check if the material is listed as a component. If yes:

  • Look at the withdrawal status and movement history.
  • If no movement is recorded, the 101 movement may not be linked to this order.

entry.title: New How-To Guides for Adapting Floorplan Manager Applications in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
In this blog I would like to draw your attention to two new How-To Guides that explain in detail how to create, enhance, and adapt Floorplan Manager (FPM) applications in the latest SAP S/4HANA releases.

Many SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud UIs are based on Floorplan Manager for Web Dynpro ABAP. This proven UI technology continues to play an important role in SAP S/4HANA 2025 and provides powerful capabilities for customer-specific adaptations without modification.

1. How to Create, Enhance, and Adapt FPM Applications for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (On-Premise and Private Cloud Edition)

This guide, valid for SAP_UI 8.16 (delivered with ABAP Platform 2025 as part of SAP S/4HANA 2025), provides a comprehensive overview of the different options that Floorplan Manager offers for customer adaptations and discusses their advantages and drawbacks.

It covers in detail how to:

  • Create and structure an FPM-based application

  • Adapt applications using Customizing, Enhancement, Deep-Copy, and Context-Based Adaptations (CBA)

  • Use the FPM Application Hierarchy Browser and FLUID (Flexible UI Designer)

  • Apply best practices to choose the right adaptation technique for your scenario

With ABAP Platform 2025, the guide also introduces updates to the FPM Mobile Enabler and improved transport handling for Context-Based Adaptations (CBAL/CBAS objects).

Download the guide (PDF)

2. How to Adapt Floorplan Manager Applications as of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

This second guide focuses on adaptation options available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Release SAP_BASIS 916 / S/4HANA 2508).

It explains how key users (with role SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC) can adapt FPM applications via:

  • Customizing using the Adapt UI function

  • Context-Based Adaptations (CBA) for role- or device-specific variants

  • Transport of adaptations using Software Collections via the Export / Import Software Collection apps

The document includes step-by-step examples on how to simplify an FPM application and make it responsive for mobile devices using CBAs and the Device Type dimension.

Download the guide (PDF)

Both documents have been updated for the 2025 releases and provide a consistent, hands-on overview of the adaptation capabilities of Floorplan Manager in both On-Premise/Private Cloud and Public Cloud environments.

we are still stepping in the dark. The trace looks fine. Only at the end it is somehow corrupted.
We have discovered an RFC bug that caused intermittent problems when the ODBC driver was used in HANA SDA and will publish a new driver patch shortly. I hope that this RFC bug fix will also fix your intermittent problems.

If the new driver patch does not help we may need to look at an RFC trace. To activate the RFC trace you need to set the following property in the connection string ( RfcTrace=debug ). This is our last resort since the RFC trace is very verbose and may write a large amount of data.

entry.title: Re: Report on SAP Signavio Process Intelligence data using the new OData API and SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
A small adjustment is required if the odata view exposes durations using the signavio data type Duration.

This becomes an odata data type Edm.Duration which is incorrectly mapped to Timestamp in Datasphere and generic in SAP Analytics cloud.

You should apply the function DURATION_TO_MILLISECONDS in the odata view and avoid the headache üôÇ

entry.title: Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì New target navigation to Project Financial Booklets
entry.content:
What's New?

With the release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2602, SAP has introduced a target navigation from the monitoring app Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Projects (F4767) to Project Financial Booklets . This update improves the reporting capabilities for project margin, costs, revenue, and planning data.

This enhancement allows users to access detailed financial insights directly from the object page of the monitoring app via the Related Apps dropdown menu.

Context-Sensitive Navigation

The target navigation is dynamically determined based on the project type:

  • For Project-Based Services (CPM projects), the system proposes navigation to: Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services (F7479)
  • For Project-Based Sales (EPPM projects), the system proposes navigation to: Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Enterprise Projects (F8698)

Visual Examples

Here are examples of how the navigation appears for each project type:

Professional Services Booklet

Enterprise Projects Booklet

entry.title: Re: Error Message QA495 during MIGO - Unable to move insp...
entry.content:
Hello @Sidram 

The root cause of the issue (it is not really an error) is the fact that your material is QM managed. Therefore any postings changing quality stock of the material has to be executed from QM level. That's exactly what the message says. That restriction is to keep MM and QM data consistent.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Error Message QA495 during MIGO - Unable to move insp...
entry.content:
Why you see the error message QA495 is because, when inspection type 01 (goods receipt inspection for purchase order) is active in the material master, SAP expects all inspection stock movements to be handled within the QM module, not via inventory transactions like MIGO or MB1B. Movement type 321 is valid, but only when triggered automatically after a usage decision is made in transaction QA11 or QA32.

To fix this, use transaction QA11 (or QA32 for mass processing), Enter the inspection lot number, Make the usage decision (e.g., "Accepted"), In the stock posting tab, choose to move stock to Unrestricted and save the decision ‚Äî SAP will automatically post movement type 321.

Go to mm02 for that material and navigate to QM view. Confirm that inspection type 01 is active. If you want to allow manual movement, you‚Äôd need to deactivate inspection type 01 ‚Äî but this is not recommended unless you're changing your quality process.

entry.title: Re: A production order compnonent material 101 mvmt displ...
entry.content:
Check the IDOC type and processing function module (e.g., MBGMCR, MBGMCR03). Confirm whether the IDOC is configured to trigger automatic confirmation or just goods receipt. Look at WE02/WE05 for the IDOC status ‚Äî was it fully processed (status 53)?

In CO03, check:

  • Component Overview: Is the material flagged for backflush?
  • Control Key in routing: Does it allow automatic confirmation?
  • Confirmation parameters: Is auto-confirmation enabled?

If the component is marked for backflush but no confirmation occurred, check if work center or routing is missing backflush settings. Confirm that movement type 101 is correctly linked to the operation.

If IDOC triggers a BAPI (e.g., BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE), check whether confirmation logic is included. Look for any custom enhancement or user exit that might be suppressing confirmation.
